Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Howard Fairbrother of Johns Hopkins University. Prof. Fairbrother and his research group will study the surface interactions that regulate the behavior of nanoparticles in aqueous environments by measuring particle-surface interactions of carbon nanotubes and gold nanoparticles in model environmental systems. The study will make use of state of the art instrumentation to study these interactions including atomic force microscopy (AFM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and UV-VIS absorption spectroscopy. Surface properties will be assayed using zeta potential measurements, potentiometric titrations and chemical derivatization techniques in conjunction with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

The study will lead to a significantly improved fundamental understanding of nanoparticle behavior in aquatic environments, which will enable the rational synthesis of safe-by-design nanoparticles. The development of safe materials, including nanoparticles is a priority area for NSF and the nation. The study will provide excellent training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students in an area of research of great societal importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with the behavior of nanoparticles (NPs) in aquatic environments, which is intimately dependent upon their interactions with environmental interfaces (e.g. mineral surfaces). These interactions are themselves the net result of electrostatic, van der Waals and steric interactions that exist between NPs and the surfaces they encounter in aquatic environments. Understanding how the relative contribution of each interaction depends on the NP, the environmental interface and the solution chemistry requires well characterized NPs and measurements of net NP-surface potentials on the order of kT, which are not easy using traditional analytical techniques. To tackle this issue, we used state-of-the-art, nonintrusive optical microscopy measurements of particle-surface interactions with established NP functionalization and characterization strategies.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research was related to the fundamental and technological insights gained into how chemically complex and diverse array of NPs interaction with surfaces as part of regulating their behavior aquatic environments. The broader impacts of the proposed research included scientific and technological outcomes related to improved fundamental understanding of NP behavior in aquatic environments, training of graduate students, and inclusion of research findings in education and outreach programs.

The outcomes of this research, which are captured in refereed journal articles, include a better understanding of how NPs interact with surface in aquatic environments. Findings include: (1) direct measurements and theoretical models of unusual NP interactions with gel layers on model mineral surfaces, (2) colloidal NP rod interactions that control their transport in model porous media, and (3) ultra-sensitive measurement of kT-scale interactions between NPs and cell surfaces including both physical and chemical topography.
